awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Evaluating the Origins of Multidecadal Variability in Late Holocene Indian Summer Monsoon Rainfall in Nepal
awd_abstract_narration:
The research team aims to develop a replicated, 4000-year-long, precisely dated, sub-decadally resolved, multi-proxy stalagmite reconstruction of Indian Summer Monsoon (ISM) rainfall in Nepal and to couple this record with climate model simulations to examine the nature and origins of multidecadal monsoon variability during different climate states of the late Holocene.  

The ISM supplies nearly seventy percent of South Asia’s annual precipitation, serving as the primary water resource for agriculture and the myriad of natural environments, including glaciers, across the region. Over the last century and a half, ISM rainfall has been positively correlated at multidecadal time scales with sea surface temperatures in the North Atlantic Ocean. However, in the last twenty years, this link appears to have been broken, with monsoon rainfall over India failing to increase despite a much warmer North Atlantic. This shift has profound consequences for regional ecosystems and the approximately two billion people living in South Asia. 

The potential Broader Impacts include a deeper understanding of a climatological system which impacts large human population centers, capacity building and expertise exchange with international colleagues, support of students involved with the research, and public outreach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Indian Summer Monsoon (ISM) supplies ~70% of South Asia’s annual precipitation, serving as the primary water source for agriculture and other natural environments, including glaciers, across the region. Over the last 150 years, ISM rainfall has been positively correlated with sea surface temperatures in the North Atlantic Ocean. However, in the last 20 years, this link appears to be weaker, with monsoon rainfall over India failing to increase despite much warmer North Atlantic Ocean temperatures. This shift has profound consequences for regional ecosystems and the approximately two billion people living in South Asia. Understanding the nature and origins of multidecadal ISM variability represents a primary challenge to climate proxy and modeling communities - a void this work has begun to fill.

To date, the work has included sampling for U-Th dates and oxygen and carbon isotopes on stalagmites from central Nepal. Together, these elucidate the dynamics of precipitation in central Nepal over the last ~4000 years. The work with stalagmites and sampling of precipitation for isotopes has developed a strong modern calibration for wet season/dry season rainfall and stalagmite carbon isotope ratios. Additionally, a suppression of wet season and dry season rainfall during a two-year period coincident with the large eruption in 1257 CE of Mt. Samalas was identified, consistent with climate model simulations for that time period.

The socioeconomic importance of the ISM in Nepal is immense as many watersheds are highly populated, almost entirely cultivated, and totally reliant on monsoon rainfall as opposed to other water sources such as groundwater or snowmelt. Additionally, communities in the foothills and mountains are vulnerable to frequent landslides closely tied to summer precipitation. Therefore, better understanding the nature of multidecadal variability in ISM rainfall with research such as this allows for more accurate long-term preparation for extended shifts in precipitation.

To date, an international team of collaborators have contributed to this work including senior faculty and undergraduate researchers as well as a cave tour guide in Nepal. This citizen science aspect of the project has greatly contributed to the success of this project. A total of five undergraduate students from Cornell College and the University of Washington have been substantially involved in all aspects of the research including advanced isotope and mass spectrometry training, fieldwork experiences, and work with climate models. This work has led to several undergraduate theses. The results of this research have been presented at national and international meetings by principal investigators of this grant.  Several presentations by undergraduate students have also been given at national meetings and at college-sponsored symposiums. Once all analyses are complete, data will be publicly available on NOAA Paleoclimate.
